Thank you for pointing out the exception. It seems the OneHotEncoder didn't create the 'group_H' column because it was set to drop the first category
by default. Here's the corrected code.

# FULL CODE SENT BY LLM IS SHOWN AS A DIFF WITH PREVIOUS CODE
-enc = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, drop='first')
+enc = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, drop=None) # do not drop any category
======================================================================================================================================================

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<12> - <-1> [3 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Code is freshly re-posted, as if it was the FIRST response.
[13] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the requested analysis:
# IMPORT

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import chi2_contingency, kruskal
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import pickle

# LOAD DATA

TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS

TimeToInfection.sex.replace("", np.nan, inplace=True)
TimeToInfection.age.fillna(TimeToInfection.age.mean(), inplace=True)
Symptoms.sex.replace("", np.nan, inplace=True)

# merge dataset on 'ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS

# No descriptive statistics tables are needed.

# PREPROCESSING

# Creating dummy variables
enc = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, drop=None) # do not drop any category
df_enc = enc.fit_transform(df[['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']])
ohe_cols_df = pd.DataFrame(df_enc, columns=enc.get_feature_names_out(['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']), index=df.index)
df = df.join(ohe_cols_df)

# ANALYSIS

## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups adjusted for confounding variables"
kruskal_test = kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1],
                       df['symptom_number'][df['group_I']==1],
                       df['symptom_number'][df['group_V']==1])
df1 = pd.DataFrame([kruskal_test.statistic, kruskal_test.pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types adjusted for confounding variables"
kruskal_test_variant = kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['variant_omicron']==1],
                               df['symptom_number'][df['variant_delta']==1])
df2 = pd.DataFrame([kruskal_test_variant.statistic, kruskal_test_variant.pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')
# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS

additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

+        TimeToInfection[col] = TimeToInfection[col].astype(int)

[15] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the revised code to perform the requested analysis:
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import kruskal
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import warnings
import pickle

# Suppress warnings
warnings.simplefilter(action='ignore', category=FutureWarning)

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
TimeToInfection.sex.replace("", np.nan, inplace=True)
TimeToInfection.age.fillna(TimeToInfection.age.mean(), inplace=True)
Symptoms.sex.replace("", np.nan, inplace=True)

# ensure both dataframes use same type for columns
merge_cols = ['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask']
for col in merge_cols:
    dtype_infection = TimeToInfection[col].dtype
    dtype_symptoms = Symptoms[col].dtype
    if dtype_infection != dtype_symptoms:
        upcast = dtype_infection if dtype_infection.kind in 'fc' else dtype_symptoms
        TimeToInfection[col] = TimeToInfection[col].astype(upcast)
        Symptoms[col] = Symptoms[col].astype(upcast)

# merge dataset on 'ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=merge_cols)

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
# No descriptive statistics tables are needed.

# PREPROCESSING
# Creating dummy variables
enc = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, drop=None) # do not drop any category
df_enc = enc.fit_transform(df[['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']])
ohe_cols_df = pd.DataFrame(df_enc, columns=enc.get_feature_names_out(['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']), index=df.index)
df = df.join(ohe_cols_df)

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups adjusted for confounding variables"
kruskal_test = kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1],
                       df['symptom_number'][df['group_I']==1],
                       df['symptom_number'][df['group_V']==1])
df1 = pd.DataFrame([kruskal_test.statistic, kruskal_test.pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types adjusted for confounding variables"
kruskal_test_variant = kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['variant_omicron']==1],
                               df['symptom_number'][df['variant_delta']==1])
df2 = pd.DataFrame([kruskal_test_variant.statistic, kruskal_test_variant.pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}
with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

On line:
30: Symptoms[col] = Symptoms[col].astype(upcast)
Your code changes the series "age" of your dataframe.

Instead of changing an existing dataframe series, please create a new series, and give it a new sensible name.

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<11> - <-1> [6 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Adding the debugged code as if it was the original response.
[12] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the analysis.
It creates the files: ['table_1.pkl', 'table_2.pkl', 'additional_results.pkl'].
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import warnings
import pickle

# Suppress warnings
warnings.simplefilter(action='ignore', category=FutureWarning)

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
TimeToInfection.sex.replace("", np.nan, inplace=True)
TimeToInfection.age.fillna(TimeToInfection.age.mean(), inplace=True)
Symptoms.sex.replace("", np.nan, inplace=True)

# Do not modify the existing Series, instead, create a new one.
TimeToInfection['age_upcast'] = TimeToInfection['age'].astype(float)
Symptoms['age_upcast'] = Symptoms['age'].astype(float)

# prepare the columns for merge
merge_cols = ['ID', 'group', 'age_upcast', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask']

# merge dataset
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=merge_cols)

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS

# No descriptive statistics tables are needed.

# PREPROCESSING

# Creating dummy variables
enc = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, drop=None)
df_enc = enc.fit_transform(df[['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']])
ohe_cols_df = pd.DataFrame(df_enc, columns=enc.get_feature_names_out(['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']), index=df.index)
df = df.join(ohe_cols_df)

# ANALYSIS

## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups adjusted for confounding variables"
kruskal_test = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1],
                       df['symptom_number'][df['group_I']==1],
                       df['symptom_number'][df['group_V']==1])
df1 = pd.DataFrame([kruskal_test.statistic, kruskal_test.pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types adjusted for confounding variables"
kruskal_test_variant = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['variant_omicron']==1],
                               df['symptom_number'][df['variant_delta']==1])
df2 = pd.DataFrame([kruskal_test_variant.statistic, kruskal_test_variant.pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

[13] ---- USER {Debugger} -> "Data Analysis Code"  ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Request Review of code flaws
The code runs without any obvious bugs, but I am worried that it may have some fundamental mathematical or statistical flaws.
I will need you to carefully check the Python code for possible flaws.
Your response should be formatted as a Python Dict[str, Tuple[str, str]], mapping the checks you have done (keys) to a Tuple[str, str], indicating
either your concern ("CONCERN", "<your concern>") or your assertion that this check is ok ("OK", "<your assertion>")..

For example:
{
    # * CHECK FOR FUNDAMENTAL FLAWS:
    # Check for any fundamental mathematical or statistical flaws in the code.
    # For example:
    "The analysis of <analysis name>": ("OK", "It is correct to ... "),
    "The analysis of <other analysis name>": ("CONCERN", "Forgot to include ..."),
    "The analysis of xxx vs yyy": ("CONCERN", "Different units were not standardized"),

    # * CHECK FOR WRONG CALCULATIONS:
    # Explicitly list all key calculation in the code and look carefully for any mistakes.
    # You should directly cut and paste the key calculations from the code, and carefully assess them.
    # For example:
    "mean_signal = np.mean(signal)": ("OK", "The mean is calculated correctly"),
    "sem_signal = np.std(signal)": ("CONCERN", "Forgot to divide by sqrt(n)"),
    "formula = 'y ~ a : b + c'": ("CONCERN", "The formula accounts for the interaction between a and b
    but does not include their main effects"),

    # * CHECK FOR MATH TRIVIALITIES:
    # Check for any mathematically trivial assessments / statistical tests.
    # For example:
    "The test of positivity of mean(z)": ("CONCERN", "By definition, all z values are positive, so the mean is triviality positive"),
    "The test A > B": ("CONCERN", "In our case, this is always true because B is negative and A is positive"),
    "The test C > 0": ("OK", "This is a valid test because ..."),
}


Notes:
(1) Generalize.
The points above are just examples, provided as a basis from which you can generalize to checks relevant to our specific code.
(2) Skip irrelevant points.
If any of the points above are not applicable, you can skip them.
(3) Add more checks.
You can also add as many other relevant checks, both positive ("OK", "...") and negative ("CONCERN", "...").
(4) Be specific.
Be specific in the description of the checks (keys) and assessment (values), so that it is clear what you are referring to in the code.

# 0    SYSTEM (  17 tokens): You are a brilliant data scientist. You are writing a Python code to analyze data.
# 1      USER (1354 tokens): # Description of the Original Dataset ## General Description General [...] ,0,1,4.5,omicron,1,5

                                                                               {'model_engine': <ModelEngine.GPT4: 'gpt-4'>}


Sure, here is the corrected code:

# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import warnings
import pickle

# Suppress warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# In TimeToInfection module, fill the missing ages with mean age
TimeToInfection['age'].fillna(TimeToInfection['age'].mean(), inplace=True)

# Merge the datasets
# Prepare the columns for the merge
merge_cols = ['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask']

# Merge datasets
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=merge_cols)

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
# No descriptive statistics table is needed.

# PREPROCESSING
# Convert categorical variables to dummy variables
ohe_cols = ['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']
encoder = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False)
df_ohe = pd.DataFrame(encoder.fit_transform(df[ohe_cols]),
                      columns=encoder.get_feature_names(ohe_cols),
                      index=df.index)
df = pd.concat([df, df_ohe], axis=1)
df.drop(columns=ohe_cols, inplace=True)

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups, adjusting for all confounding variables"
statistic, pvalue = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['group_I']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['group_V']==1])
df1 = pd.DataFrame([statistic, pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H Test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types, adjusting for all confounding variables"
statistic, pvalue = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['variant_delta']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['variant_omicron']==1])
df2 = pd.DataFrame([statistic, pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H Test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)


Please note the following:
- The NaN values in the 'sex' column in both datasets are now dropped before the analysis.
- In the preprocessing section, the categorical variables ('group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant') are converted to dummy variables for the analysis.
- After conversion, the original categorical columns are dropped to avoid redundancy.
======================================================================================================================================================

AppendMessage, Code is freshly re-posted, as if it was the FIRST response.
[15] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the requested analysis:
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import warnings
import pickle

# Suppress warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# In TimeToInfection module, fill the missing ages with mean age
TimeToInfection['age'].fillna(TimeToInfection['age'].mean(), inplace=True)

# Merge the datasets
# Prepare the columns for the merge
merge_cols = ['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask']

# Merge datasets
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=merge_cols)

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
# No descriptive statistics table is needed.

# PREPROCESSING
# Convert categorical variables to dummy variables
ohe_cols = ['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']
encoder = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False)
df_ohe = pd.DataFrame(encoder.fit_transform(df[ohe_cols]),
                      columns=encoder.get_feature_names(ohe_cols),
                      index=df.index)
df = pd.concat([df, df_ohe], axis=1)
df.drop(columns=ohe_cols, inplace=True)

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups, adjusting for all confounding variables"
statistic, pvalue = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['group_I']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['group_V']==1])
df1 = pd.DataFrame([statistic, pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H Test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types, adjusting for all confounding variables"
statistic, pvalue = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['variant_delta']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['variant_omicron']==1])
df2 = pd.DataFrame([statistic, pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H Test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

I apologize for the confusion. It looks like the sklearn version that you are using does not support the 'get_feature_names' method for OneHotEncoder.
Instead, 'get_feature_names_out' should be used for versions of sklearn 0.24 and above. I apologize once again for any confusion caused. Here is the
amended code:

# FULL CODE SENT BY LLM IS SHOWN AS A DIFF WITH PREVIOUS CODE
-df_ohe = pd.DataFrame(encoder.fit_transform(df[ohe_cols]),
-                      columns=encoder.get_feature_names(ohe_cols),
+df_ohe = pd.DataFrame(encoder.fit_transform(df[ohe_cols]),
+                      columns=encoder.get_feature_names_out(ohe_cols),

[15] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the requested analysis:
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import warnings
import pickle

# Suppress warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# In TimeToInfection module, fill the missing ages with mean age
TimeToInfection['age'].fillna(TimeToInfection['age'].mean(), inplace=True)

# Merge the datasets
# Prepare the columns for the merge
merge_cols = ['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask']

# Merge datasets
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=merge_cols)

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
# No descriptive statistics table is needed.

# PREPROCESSING
# Convert categorical variables to dummy variables
ohe_cols = ['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']
encoder = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False)
df_ohe = pd.DataFrame(encoder.fit_transform(df[ohe_cols]),
                      columns=encoder.get_feature_names_out(ohe_cols),
                      index=df.index)
df = pd.concat([df, df_ohe], axis=1)
df.drop(columns=ohe_cols, inplace=True)

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups, adjusting for all confounding variables"
statistic, pvalue = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['group_I']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['group_V']==1])
df1 = pd.DataFrame([statistic, pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H Test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types, adjusting for all confounding variables"
statistic, pvalue = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['variant_delta']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['variant_omicron']==1])
df2 = pd.DataFrame([statistic, pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H Test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)

# Coding: good practices
On line:
47: statistic, pvalue = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1],
Unpacking, or otherwise iterating over, the results of kruskal can lead to coding mistakes.

Your code should instead keep the results object and access its attributes by name when needed.
Attributes of `kruskal` results object are: `statistic`, `pvalue`

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<11> - <-1> [6 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Adding the debugged code as if it was the original response.
[12] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the analysis.
It creates the files: ['table_1.pkl', 'table_2.pkl', 'additional_results.pkl'].
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import warnings
import pickle

# Suppress warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# In TimeToInfection module, fill the missing ages with mean age
TimeToInfection['age'].fillna(TimeToInfection['age'].mean(), inplace=True)

# Merge the datasets
# Prepare the columns for the merge
merge_cols = ['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask']

# Merge datasets
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=merge_cols)

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
# No descriptive statistics table is needed.

# PREPROCESSING
# Convert categorical variables to dummy variables
ohe_cols = ['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant']
encoder = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False)
df_ohe = pd.DataFrame(encoder.fit_transform(df[ohe_cols]),
                      columns=encoder.get_feature_names_out(ohe_cols),
                      index=df.index)
df = pd.concat([df, df_ohe], axis=1)
df.drop(columns=ohe_cols, inplace=True)

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups, adjusting for all confounding variables"
kruskal_test = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['group_I']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['group_V']==1])
df1 = pd.DataFrame([kruskal_test.statistic, kruskal_test.pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H Test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types, adjusting for all confounding variables"
kruskal_test_variant = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['variant_delta']==1],
                                  df['symptom_number'][df['variant_omicron']==1])
df2 = pd.DataFrame([kruskal_test_variant.statistic, kruskal_test_variant.pvalue], columns=['Kruskal Wallis H Test'], index=['Statistic', 'P-value'])
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

[13] USER {Debugger} -> "Data Analysis Code"  : 
## Request Review of code flaws The code runs without any obvious bugs, but I am worried that it [...] clear what you are referring to in the code.

# 0    SYSTEM (  17 tokens): You are a brilliant data scientist. You are writing a Python code to analyze data.

# 2 SURROGATE (  11 tokens): Thank you for the Description of the Original Dataset.
# 3      USER ( 478 tokens): # Hypothesis Testing Plan ## Statistical considerations: ### Confounding [...] variables.

# 6 SURROGATE ( 679 tokens): Here is the code to perform the analysis. It creates the files: [...] f)
# 7      USER ( 588 tokens): ## Request Review of code flaws The code runs without any obvious bugs, but I [...] to in the code.

# 8 ASSISTANT ( 384 tokens): Here is the review of the code:  python {  # * CHECK FOR FUNDAMENTAL FLAWS:  [...] one-way ANOVA.
                                                                               {'model_engine': <ModelEngine.GPT4: 'gpt-4'>, 'temperature': 0.0}


Here is the review of the code:

{
    # * CHECK FOR FUNDAMENTAL FLAWS:
    "The analysis of symptom numbers between immunity groups": ("OK", "It is correct to use Kruskal Wallis H Test for comparing symptom numbers
between immunity groups."),
    "The analysis of symptom numbers between variant types": ("OK", "It is correct to use Kruskal Wallis H Test for comparing symptom numbers between
variant types."),

    # * CHECK FOR WRONG CALCULATIONS:
    "kruskal_test = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['group_H']==1], df['symptom_number'][df['group_I']==1],
df['symptom_number'][df['group_V']==1])": ("OK", "The Kruskal Wallis H Test is calculated correctly for comparing symptom numbers between immunity
groups."),
    "kruskal_test_variant = stats.kruskal(df['symptom_number'][df['variant_delta']==1], df['symptom_number'][df['variant_omicron']==1])": ("OK", "The
Kruskal Wallis H Test is calculated correctly for comparing symptom numbers between variant types."),

    # * CHECK FOR MATH TRIVIALITIES:
    "The test of symptom numbers between immunity groups": ("OK", "This is a valid test because symptom numbers can vary between different immunity
groups."),
    "The test of symptom numbers between variant types": ("OK", "This is a valid test because symptom numbers can vary between different variant
types."),
}

The code seems to be statistically sound. The Kruskal Wallis H Test is appropriate for comparing the symptom numbers between different groups as it is
a non-parametric method used to compare three or more unpaired groups. The test does not assume a normal distribution of the residuals, unlike the
analogous one-way ANOVA.
======================================================================================================================================================

DeleteMessages(<12> - <-1> [2 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

[13] ---- USER {Debugger} -> "Data Analysis Code"  ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Request Review of data handling
The code runs without any obvious bugs, but I am worried that it may contain some flaws in the analysis.
I will need you to carefully check the Python code for possible issues.

[14] COMMENTER -> "Data Analysis Code"  : Starting to write and debug code. Revision 3/3 (attempt 1/2).

[15] ==== ASSISTANT{'model_engine': <ModelEngine.GPT4: 'gpt-4'>} {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  ================================================

CONTEXT TOTAL (3829 tokens):
# 0    SYSTEM (  17 tokens): You are a brilliant data scientist. You are writing a Python code to analyze data.
# 1      USER (1354 tokens): # Description of the Original Dataset ## General Description General [...] ,0,1,4.5,omicron,1,5
# 2 SURROGATE (  11 tokens): Thank you for the Description of the Original Dataset.
# 3      USER ( 478 tokens): # Hypothesis Testing Plan ## Statistical considerations: ### Confounding [...] variables.
# 4 SURROGATE (  11 tokens): Thank you for the Hypothesis Testing Plan.
# 5      USER (1130 tokens): Write a complete Python code to analyze the data and create dataframes as [...] positions.
# 6 SURROGATE ( 679 tokens): Here is the code to perform the analysis. It creates the files: [...] f)
# 7      USER ( 149 tokens): # Review of all created files The code has some issues that need to be fixed: [...] ADDITIONAL RESULTS"

# 8 ASSISTANT ( 700 tokens): python # IMPORT import pandas as pd import numpy as np import pickle import [...] f)
                                                                               {'model_engine': <ModelEngine.GPT4: 'gpt-4'>}


# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import pickle
import statsmodels.api as sm
from scipy import stats
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Fill missing values in sex column with mode value
mode_sex_TimeToInfection = TimeToInfection['sex'].mode()[0]
TimeToInfection['sex'].fillna(mode_sex_TimeToInfection, inplace=True)

mode_sex_Symptoms = Symptoms['sex'].mode()[0]
Symptoms['sex'].fillna(mode_sex_Symptoms, inplace=True)

# Merge datasets on ID and sex
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms,  how='inner', on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Descriptive statistics of groups, symptom numbers and variants"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# Creating dummy variables
def create_dummies(df, columns):
    for column in columns:
        dummies = pd.get_dummies(df[column], prefix=column)
        df = pd.concat([df, dummies], axis=1)
    return df

df = create_dummies(df, ['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant'])

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups, adjusting for all confounding variables"
X = df[['group_H', 'group_I', 'group_V', 'age', 'sex_female', 'sex_male', 'comorbidity', 'using_FFP2_mask_from_TimeToInfection']]
Y = df['symptom_number']
model = sm.OLS(Y, sm.add_constant(X))
results = model.fit()
df1 = pd.DataFrame({'Adjusted R-squared': [results.rsquared_adj]})
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types, adjusting for all confounding variables"
X = df[['variant_delta', 'variant_omicron', 'age', 'sex_female', 'sex_male', 'comorbidity', 'using_FFP2_mask_from_TimeToInfection']]
Y = df['symptom_number']
model = sm.OLS(Y, sm.add_constant(X))
results = model.fit()
df2 = pd.DataFrame({'Adjusted R-squared': [results.rsquared_adj]})
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask_from_TimeToInfection'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

DeleteMessages(<14> - <-1> [1 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Code is freshly re-posted, as if it was the FIRST response.
[15] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the requested analysis:
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import pickle
import statsmodels.api as sm
from scipy import stats
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Fill missing values in sex column with mode value
mode_sex_TimeToInfection = TimeToInfection['sex'].mode()[0]
TimeToInfection['sex'].fillna(mode_sex_TimeToInfection, inplace=True)

mode_sex_Symptoms = Symptoms['sex'].mode()[0]
Symptoms['sex'].fillna(mode_sex_Symptoms, inplace=True)

# Merge datasets on ID and sex
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms,  how='inner', on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Descriptive statistics of groups, symptom numbers and variants"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# Creating dummy variables
def create_dummies(df, columns):
    for column in columns:
        dummies = pd.get_dummies(df[column], prefix=column)
        df = pd.concat([df, dummies], axis=1)
    return df

df = create_dummies(df, ['group', 'sex', 'BMI', 'variant'])

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between immunity groups, adjusting for all confounding variables"
X = df[['group_H', 'group_I', 'group_V', 'age', 'sex_female', 'sex_male', 'comorbidity', 'using_FFP2_mask_from_TimeToInfection']]
Y = df['symptom_number']
model = sm.OLS(Y, sm.add_constant(X))
results = model.fit()
df1 = pd.DataFrame({'Adjusted R-squared': [results.rsquared_adj]})
df1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Testing difference in symptom numbers between variant types, adjusting for all confounding variables"
X = df[['variant_delta', 'variant_omicron', 'age', 'sex_female', 'sex_male', 'comorbidity', 'using_FFP2_mask_from_TimeToInfection']]
Y = df['symptom_number']
model = sm.OLS(Y, sm.add_constant(X))
results = model.fit()
df2 = pd.DataFrame({'Adjusted R-squared': [results.rsquared_adj]})
df2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask_from_TimeToInfection'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

You should use the "ols" function instead, so that the formula is clearly specified as a string.
Reminder: For interactions, if any, use the `*` operator in the formula, rather than manually multiplying the variables.

Here is the revised code using statsmodels' "ols" function:

# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import pickle
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Merge data files on common columns
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity"
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ variant + age + sex + comorbidity'
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<14> - <-1> [3 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Code is freshly re-posted, as if it was the FIRST response.
[15] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the requested analysis:
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import pickle
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Merge data files on common columns
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity"
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ variant + age + sex + comorbidity'
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)

clear that it is not a mistake.

AppendMessage, Adding the debugged code as if it was the original response.
[12] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the analysis.
It creates the files: ['table_0.pkl', 'table_1.pkl', 'table_2.pkl', 'additional_results.pkl'].
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import pickle
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv('TimeToInfection.csv')
Symptoms = pd.read_csv('Symptoms.csv')

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Merge data files on common columns
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection, Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.set_index(['Group', 'Variant'], inplace=True)
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity"
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ variant + age + sex + comorbidity'
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

+## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity for infected individuals only"

This Python code corrects the issue from the previous code. It changes the information used for the statistical tests to only include healthcare
workers that got infected. It does so by adding a selection filter 'TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1' when merging the two dataframes. This way,
only the observations where an infection occurred are included in the analysis.

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<11> - <-1> [4 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Adding the debugged code as if it was the original response.
[12] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the analysis.
It creates the files: ['table_0.pkl', 'table_1.pkl', 'table_2.pkl', 'additional_results.pkl'].
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import pickle
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv("TimeToInfection.csv")
Symptoms = pd.read_csv("Symptoms.csv")

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Join Data files
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant for infected individuals only"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.set_index(['Group', 'Variant'], inplace=True)
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity for infected individuals only"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity for infected individuals only"
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ variant + age + sex + comorbidity'
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

Here is the content of the file(s) that the code created for our scientific paper:

"table_0.pkl":
```output
               Average Symptom Number  Standard Deviation  Count
Group Variant
H     delta                     3.333               2.251      6
      omicron                   3.068               2.064    103
I     delta                     4.429                2.76      7
      omicron                   4.069               1.771     29
N     delta                     4.833               2.365     30
      omicron                   4.306               2.328     36
V     delta                     4.333                2.32    129
      omicron                   3.683               2.089    419
```

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<11> - <-1> [4 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Adding the debugged code as if it was the original response.
[12] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the analysis.
It creates the files: ['table_0.pkl', 'table_1.pkl', 'table_2.pkl', 'additional_results.pkl'].
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf
import pickle

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv("TimeToInfection.csv")
Symptoms = pd.read_csv("Symptoms.csv")

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Join Data files
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant for infected individuals only"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.set_index(['Group', 'Variant'], inplace=True)
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing is needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity for infected individuals only"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity and interaction between group and variant for
infected individuals only"
df['interaction'] = df['group'] +'_'+ df['variant'] # Create interaction term
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ interaction + age + sex + comorbidity'
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
# Include interaction term in the result table
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

# FULL CODE SENT BY LLM IS SHOWN AS A DIFF WITH PREVIOUS CODE
-df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI', 'using_FFP2_mask'])

+formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ group + variant + group:variant + age + sex + comorbidity' # Create interaction term

variant.

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<14> - <-1> [1 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Code is freshly re-posted, as if it was the FIRST response.
[15] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the requested analysis:
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf
import pickle

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv("TimeToInfection.csv")
Symptoms = pd.read_csv("Symptoms.csv")

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Join Data files
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI'])

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant for infected individuals only"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.set_index(['Group', 'Variant'], inplace=True)
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing is needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity for infected individuals only"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity and interaction between group and variant for
infected individuals only"
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ group + variant + group:variant + age + sex + comorbidity' # Create interaction term
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
# Include interaction term in the result table
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

'months_since_immunisation', 'time_dose1_to_dose_2', 'vaccinetype', 'day_interval_start', 'day_interval_stop', 'infection_event', 'comorbidity',
'using_FFP2_mask_y', 'months_until_reinfection', 'variant', 'booster_over7_days_before', 'symptom_number']

[17] ==== ASSISTANT{'model_engine': <ModelEngine.GPT4: 'gpt-4'>} {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  ================================================

#10 ASSISTANT ( 610 tokens): Here is the code to perform the requested analysis: python # IMPORT import [...] f)

Here is the code to perform the requested analysis:
# FULL CODE SENT BY LLM IS SHOWN AS A DIFF WITH PREVIOUS CODE
-df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI'])
+df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI'], suffixes=('_x', '_y'))
@@ -51 +51 @@
-    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask'].sum()
+    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask_y'].sum()
======================================================================================================================================================

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<11> - <-1> [6 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Adding the debugged code as if it was the original response.
[12] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the analysis.
It creates the files: ['table_0.pkl', 'table_1.pkl', 'table_2.pkl', 'additional_results.pkl'].
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf
import pickle

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv("TimeToInfection.csv")
Symptoms = pd.read_csv("Symptoms.csv")

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Join Data files
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI'], suffixes=('_x', '_y'))

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant for infected individuals only"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.set_index(['Group', 'Variant'], inplace=True)
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing is needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity for infected individuals only"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex and comorbidity and interaction between group and variant for
infected individuals only"
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ group + variant + group:variant + age + sex + comorbidity' # Create interaction term
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
# Include interaction term in the result table
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask_y'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

[13] ---- USER {Debugger} -> "Data Analysis Code"  ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

```output
    'Number of comorbidity cases': 272.0,
```

CodeRunner: Using cached output.
DeleteMessages(<11> - <-1> [4 MESSAGES]) -> Data Analysis Code

AppendMessage, Adding the debugged code as if it was the original response.
[12] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "Data Analysis Code"  =============================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the analysis.
It creates the files: ['table_0.pkl', 'table_1.pkl', 'table_2.pkl', 'additional_results.pkl'].
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf
import pickle

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv("TimeToInfection.csv")
Symptoms = pd.read_csv("Symptoms.csv")

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Join Data files
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI'], suffixes=('_x', '_y'))

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant for infected individuals only"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.set_index(['Group', 'Variant'], inplace=True)
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing is needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, variant, adjusting for age, sex, and comorbidity for infected individuals only"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + variant + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex, comorbidity and interaction between group and variant for
infected individuals only"
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ group + variant + group:variant + age + sex + comorbidity' # Create interaction term
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
# Include interaction term in the result table
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask_y'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
======================================================================================================================================================

# Data Analysis Code
Here is our Data Analysis Code:
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf
import pickle

# LOAD DATA
TimeToInfection = pd.read_csv("TimeToInfection.csv")
Symptoms = pd.read_csv("Symptoms.csv")

# DATASET PREPARATIONS
# Drop the rows that contain missing value in the 'sex' column
TimeToInfection.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)
Symptoms.dropna(subset=['sex'], inplace=True)

# Join Data files
df = pd.merge(TimeToInfection[TimeToInfection.infection_event == 1], Symptoms, on=['ID', 'group', 'age', 'sex', 'BMI'], suffixes=('_x', '_y'))

# DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS
## Table 0: "Distribution of group, symptom number and variant for infected individuals only"
grouped_df = df.groupby(['group', 'variant']).agg({'symptom_number': ['mean', 'std', 'count']}).reset_index()
df0 = pd.DataFrame(grouped_df)
df0.columns = ['Group', 'Variant', 'Average Symptom Number', 'Standard Deviation', 'Count']
df0.set_index(['Group', 'Variant'], inplace=True)
df0.to_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# PREPROCESSING
# No preprocessing is needed in this case

# ANALYSIS
## Table 1: "Association between symptom numbers and group, variant, adjusting for age, sex, and comorbidity for infected individuals only"
formula1 = 'symptom_number ~ group + variant + age + sex + comorbidity'
model1 = smf.ols(formula1, data=df)
results1 = model1.fit()
table1 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results1.params, 'p-value': results1.pvalues})
table1.to_pickle('table_1.pkl')

## Table 2: "Association between symptom numbers and variant, adjusting for age, sex, comorbidity and interaction between group and variant for
infected individuals only"
formula2 = 'symptom_number ~ group + variant + group:variant + age + sex + comorbidity' # Create interaction term
model2 = smf.ols(formula2, data=df)
results2 = model2.fit()
# Include interaction term in the result table
table2 = pd.DataFrame({'coef': results2.params, 'p-value': results2.pvalues})
table2.to_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# SAVE ADDITIONAL RESULTS
additional_results = {
    'Total number of observations': df.shape[0],
    'Number of comorbidity cases': df['comorbidity'].sum(),
    'Number of people using FFP2 mask': df['using_FFP2_mask_y'].sum()
}

with open('additional_results.pkl', 'wb') as f:
    pickle.dump(additional_results, f)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thank you for the Data Analysis Code.

Do not provide a line-by-line explanation, rather provide a high-level explanation of the code in a language suitable for a Methods section of a
research paper.
Focus on analysis steps. There is no need to explain trivial parts, like reading/writing a file, etc.
Also explain what does the code write into the "additional_results.pkl" file.

```latex
\section{Code Explanation}
```

```latex
\section{Code Explanation}
The provided code performs data analysis on two datasets - "TimeToInfection.csv" and "Symptoms.csv. After loading and preparing the datasets, the code
joins the data files based on specific columns and filters out rows with missing values in the 'sex' column.

Descriptive statistics are calculated, presenting the distribution of symptom numbers across different vaccination groups and virus variants for
infected individuals. Two statistical models are then created to assess the association between symptom numbers and various factors, adjusting for
age, sex, and comorbidity. The first model examines the impact of group and variant on symptom numbers, while the second model introduces an
interaction term to evaluate their combined effect.

The analysis results, including coefficients and p-values, are saved in pickle files named 'table_0.pkl', 'table_1.pkl', and 'table_2.pkl' for further
inspection or future reference. Additionally, the code saves extra results in 'additional_results.pkl' file, capturing details such as the total
number of observations, the count of comorbidity cases, and the number of individuals using FFP2 masks during the study.
```

```output
               Average Symptom Number  Standard Deviation  Count
Group Variant
H     delta                     3.333               2.251      6
      omicron                   3.068               2.064    103
I     delta                     4.429                2.76      7
      omicron                   4.069               1.771     29
N     delta                     4.833               2.365     30
      omicron                   4.306               2.328     36
V     delta                     4.333                2.32    129
      omicron                   3.683               2.089    419
```
"table_1.pkl":
```output
                       coef   p-value
Intercept             3.891    <1e-06
group[T.I]            1.015    0.0174
group[T.N]            1.288  0.000292
group[T.V]           0.7232   0.00204
variant[T.omicron]   -0.512   0.00923
sex[T.male]            -0.4     0.053
age                -0.01297     0.093
comorbidity          0.5724  0.000522
```

```output
                                  coef   p-value
Intercept                         3.86  4.71e-05
group[T.I]                      0.5089      0.68
group[T.N]                       1.277     0.186
group[T.V]                      0.7977      0.37
variant[T.omicron]             -0.4751     0.597
sex[T.male]                    -0.4048    0.0514
group[T.I]:variant[T.omicron]   0.6232     0.636
group[T.N]:variant[T.omicron]  0.04547     0.966
group[T.V]:variant[T.omicron] -0.08818     0.924
age                             -0.013    0.0936
comorbidity                     0.5695  0.000573
```

[10] COMMENTER -> "LaTeX Table Design Code"  <after_background>  : Background messages completed. Requesting "LaTeX Table Design code".

[11] ---- USER {InterpretationReviewer} -> "LaTeX Table Design Code"  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Please write a Python code to convert and re-style the "table_?.pkl" dataframes created by our "Data Analysis Code" into latex tables suitable for our
scientific paper.

Your code should use the following 3 custom functions provided for import from `my_utils`:

def to_latex_with_note(df, filename: str, caption: str, label: str, note: str = None, legend: Dict[str, str] = None, **kwargs):
    """
    Converts a DataFrame to a LaTeX table with optional note and legend added below the table.

    Parameters:
    - df, filename, caption, label: as in `df.to_latex`.
    - note (optional): Additional note below the table.
    - legend (optional): Dictionary mapping abbreviations to full names.
    - **kwargs: Additional arguments for `df.to_latex`.
    """

def is_str_in_df(df: pd.DataFrame, s: str):
    return any(s in level for level in getattr(df.index, 'levels', [df.index]) + getattr(df.columns, 'levels', [df.columns]))

AbbrToNameDef = Dict[Any, Tuple[Optional[str], Optional[str]]]

def split_mapping(abbrs_to_names_and_definitions: AbbrToNameDef):
    abbrs_to_names = {abbr: name for abbr, (name, definition) in abbrs_to_names_and_definitions.items() if name is not None}
    names_to_definitions = {name or abbr: definition for abbr, (name, definition) in abbrs_to_names_and_definitions.items() if definition is not None}
    return abbrs_to_names, names_to_definitions


Your code should:

* Rename column and row names: You should provide a new name to any column or row label that is abbreviated or technical, or that is otherwise not
self-explanatory.

* Provide legend definitions: You should provide a full definition for any name (or new name) that satisfies any of the following:
- Remains abbreviated, or not self-explanatory, even after renaming.
- Is an ordinal/categorical variable that requires clarification of the meaning of each of its possible values.
- Contains unclear notation, like '*' or ':'
- Represents a numeric variable that has units, that need to be specified.

To avoid re-naming mistakes, you should define for each table a dictionary, `mapping: AbbrToNameDef`, which maps any original column and row names
that are abbreviated or not self-explanatory to an optional new name, and an optional definition.
If different tables share several common labels, then you can build a `shared_mapping`, from which you can extract the relevant labels for each table.

Overall, the code must have the following structure:

# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
from my_utils import to_latex_with_note, is_str_in_df, split_mapping, AbbrToNameDef

# PREPARATION FOR ALL TABLES
# <As applicable, define a shared mapping for labels that are common to all tables. For example:>
shared_mapping: AbbrToNameDef = {
    'AvgAge': ('Avg. Age', 'Average age, years'),
    'BT': ('Body Temperature', '1: Normal, 2: High, 3: Very High'),
    'W': ('Weight', 'Participant weight, kg'),
    'MRSA': (None, 'Infected with Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, 1: Yes, 0: No'),
    ...: (..., ...),
}
# <This is of course just an example. Consult with the "Description of the Original Dataset" and the "Data Analysis Code" for choosing the labels and
their proper scientific names and definitions.>

# TABLE 0:
df0 = pd.read_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# FORMAT VALUES <include this sub-section only as applicable>
# <Rename technical values to scientifically-suitable values. For example:>
df0['MRSA'] = df0['MRSA'].apply(lambda x: 'Yes' if x == 1 else 'No')

# RENAME ROWS AND COLUMNS <include this sub-section only as applicable>
# <Rename any abbreviated or not self-explanatory table labels to scientifically-suitable names.>
# <Use the `shared_mapping` if applicable. For example:>
mapping0 = dict((k, v) for k, v in shared_mapping.items() if is_str_in_df(df0, k))
mapping0 |= {
    'PV': ('P-value', None),
    'CI': (None, '95% Confidence Interval'),
    'Sex_Age': ('Age * Sex', 'Interaction term between Age and Sex'),
}
abbrs_to_names0, legend0 = split_mapping(mapping0)
df0 = df0.rename(columns=abbrs_to_names0, index=abbrs_to_names0)

# SAVE AS LATEX:
to_latex_with_note(
    df0, 'table_0.tex',
    caption="<choose a caption suitable for a table in a scientific paper>",
    label='table:<chosen table label>',
    note="<If needed, add a note to provide any additional information that is not captured in the caption>",
    legend=legend0)
# TABLE <?>:
# <etc, all 'table_?.pkl' files>

Do not provide a sketch or pseudocode; write a complete runnable code including all '# HEADERS' sections.
Do not create any graphics, figures or any plots.

Here's your Python code to convert the "table_?.pkl" dataframes created by your "Data Analysis Code" into LaTeX tables suitable for your scientific
paper:

# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
from my_utils import to_latex_with_note, is_str_in_df, split_mapping
# MAPPINGS FOR ALL TABLES
shared_mapping = {
    'coef': ('Coefficient', 'Estimated effect on the symptom number'),
    'p-value': ('P-value', 'Statistical significance of the estimated effect'),
    'age': ('Age', 'Age in years'),
    'sex': ('Sex', 'Sex of the health worker'),
    'comorbidity': ('Comorbidity', 'If any pre-existing comorbity existed, 1: Yes, 0: No'),
}

# TABLE 0:
df0 = pd.read_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# MAPPING FOR TABLE 0
table0_mapping = {
    'Average Symptom Number': ('Mean Symptom Count', 'Average number of symptoms from delta or omicron variant infection'),
    'Standard Deviation': ('Symptom Count Standard Deviation', 'Standard deviation of symptom counts for delta or omicron variant infection'),
    'Count': ('Infection Count', 'Number of delta or omicron variant infections'),
}

abbrs_to_names0, legend0 = split_mapping({**shared_mapping, **table0_mapping})
df0 = df0.rename(columns=abbrs_to_names0, index=abbrs_to_names0)

# SAVE AS LATEX:
to_latex_with_note(
    df0, 'table_0.tex',
    caption='Summary statistics of health worker infections by different SARS-CoV-2 variants',
    label='table_0',
    note='Summary statistics including the count of health worker infections, average symptom count, and '
         'standard deviation of symptom counts for different variants.',
    legend=legend0)
# TABLE 1:
df1 = pd.read_pickle('table_1.pkl')

# MAPPING FOR TABLE 1
table1_mapping = {
    'group': ('Immunity Group', '"N" (no immunity), "V" (twice vaccinated, uninfected), "I" (infected, unvaccinated), "H" (hybrid: infected and ≥1
vaccination)'),
    'variant': ('SARS-CoV-2 Variant', 'Variant of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, "delta" or "omicron"'),
}

abbrs_to_names1, legend1 = split_mapping({**shared_mapping, **table1_mapping})
df1 = df1.rename(columns=abbrs_to_names1, index=abbrs_to_names1)

# SAVE AS LATEX:
to_latex_with_note(
    df2, 'table_2.tex',
    caption='Model estimates for interaction effects',
    label='table_2',
    note='Table reports the pooled OLS regression coefficient estimates which gives interaction effects between symptom numbers and immunity group,
variant of virus, adjustment for impacted factors.',
    legend=legend2)

This code replaces the technical row and column names to more descriptive ones, and it includes a note and legend for each table to provide a deeper
understanding of the table content. The code can be easily extended for any additional tables by following the same structure. Please make sure to
modify the captions, labels, and notes according to your preference.

[13] ==== SURROGATE {Performer} -> "LaTeX Table Design Code"  ========================================================================================
Here is the code to perform the requested analysis:
# IMPORT
import pandas as pd
from my_utils import to_latex_with_note, is_str_in_df, split_mapping
# MAPPINGS FOR ALL TABLES
shared_mapping = {
    'coef': ('Coefficient', 'Estimated effect on the symptom number'),
    'p-value': ('P-value', 'Statistical significance of the estimated effect'),
    'age': ('Age', 'Age in years'),
    'sex': ('Sex', 'Sex of the health worker'),
    'comorbidity': ('Comorbidity', 'If any pre-existing comorbity existed, 1: Yes, 0: No'),
}

# TABLE 0:
df0 = pd.read_pickle('table_0.pkl')

# MAPPING FOR TABLE 0
table0_mapping = {
    'Average Symptom Number': ('Mean Symptom Count', 'Average number of symptoms from delta or omicron variant infection'),
    'Standard Deviation': ('Symptom Count Standard Deviation', 'Standard deviation of symptom counts for delta or omicron variant infection'),
    'Count': ('Infection Count', 'Number of delta or omicron variant infections'),
}

abbrs_to_names0, legend0 = split_mapping({**shared_mapping, **table0_mapping})
df0 = df0.rename(columns=abbrs_to_names0, index=abbrs_to_names0)

# SAVE AS LATEX:
to_latex_with_note(
    df0, 'table_0.tex',
    caption='Summary statistics of health worker infections by different SARS-CoV-2 variants',
    label='table_0',
    note='Summary statistics including the count of health worker infections, average symptom count, and '
         'standard deviation of symptom counts for different variants.',
    legend=legend0)
# TABLE 1:
df1 = pd.read_pickle('table_1.pkl')

# MAPPING FOR TABLE 1
table1_mapping = {
    'group': ('Immunity Group', '"N" (no immunity), "V" (twice vaccinated, uninfected), "I" (infected, unvaccinated), "H" (hybrid: infected and ≥1
vaccination)'),
    'variant': ('SARS-CoV-2 Variant', 'Variant of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, "delta" or "omicron"'),
}

abbrs_to_names1, legend1 = split_mapping({**shared_mapping, **table1_mapping})
df1 = df1.rename(columns=abbrs_to_names1, index=abbrs_to_names1)

# SAVE AS LATEX:
to_latex_with_note(
    df1, 'table_1.tex',
    caption='Model estimates of the factors influencing symptom numbers',
    label='table_1',
    note='Table reports the pooled OLS regression coefficient estimates which gives associations between symptom numbers and immunity group, variant
of virus, adjustment for impacted factors.',
    legend=legend1)
# TABLE 2:
df2 = pd.read_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# MAPPING FOR TABLE 2
table2_mapping = {
    'group:variant': ('Group:Variant', 'Interaction effect of immunity group and the SARS-CoV-2 variant'),
}

abbrs_to_names2, legend2 = split_mapping({**shared_mapping, **table1_mapping, **table2_mapping})
df2 = df2.rename(columns=abbrs_to_names2, index=abbrs_to_names2)

# SAVE AS LATEX:
to_latex_with_note(
    df0, 'table_0.tex',
    caption='Summary statistics of health worker infections by different SARS-CoV-2 variants',
    label='table:0',
    note='Summary statistics including the count of health worker infections, average symptom count, and \
    standard deviation of symptom counts for different variants.',
    legend=legend0)
# TABLE 1:
df1 = pd.read_pickle('table_1.pkl')

# Prepare the data mappings for table 1
mapping1: AbbrToNameDef = {
    'group': ('Immunity Group', '"N" (no immunity), "V" (twice vaccinated, uninfected), "I" (infected, unvaccinated), "H" (hybrid: infected and ≥1
vaccination)'),
    'variant': ('SARS-CoV-2 Variant', 'Variant of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, "delta" or "omicron"'),
}

# Apply the mappings
abbrs_to_names1, legend1 = split_mapping({**shared_mapping, **mapping1})
df1 = df1.rename(columns=abbrs_to_names1, index=abbrs_to_names1)

# Save as LaTeX:
to_latex_with_note(
    df1, 'table_1.tex',
    caption='Model estimates of the factors influencing symptom numbers',
    label='table:1',
    note='Table reports the pooled OLS regression coefficient estimates which gives associations between symptom numbers and immunity group, variant
of virus, and adjustment for impacted factors.',
    legend=legend1)
# TABLE 2:
df2 = pd.read_pickle('table_2.pkl')

# Prepare the data mappings for table 2
mapping2: AbbrToNameDef = {
    'group:variant': ('Group:Variant', 'Interaction effect of immunity group and the SARS-CoV-2 variant'),
}

# Apply the mappings
abbrs_to_names2, legend2 = split_mapping({**shared_mapping, **mapping1, **mapping2})
df2 = df2.rename(columns=abbrs_to_names2, index=abbrs_to_names2)

# Save as LaTeX:
to_latex_with_note(
    df2, 'table_2.tex',
    caption='Model estimates for interaction effects',
    label='table_2',
    note='Table reports the pooled OLS regression coefficient estimates which gives interaction effects between symptom numbers and immunity group,
variant of virus, adjustment for impacted factors.',
    legend=legend2)

This code replaces the technical row and column names to more descriptive ones, and it includes a note and legend for each table to provide a deeper
understanding of the table content. The code can be easily extended for any additional tables by following the same structure. Please make sure to
modify the captions, labels, and notes according to your preference.
